bibl.title: Letter from Walter Reed to Emilie Lawrence Reed, [June 15?, 1902]

div1.p: Reed writes about last night's grand dinner where he was given the second place of honor at dinner in recognition of his work, above men who awed him. He is distressed to learn about their fruit trees.

div1.head: Letter from Walter Reed to Emilie Lawrence Reed, [June 15?, 1902]
div1.p:
I got back
from Boston late last night
in very good shape, although a
little bit tired with my outing.
Had a perfectly delightful time-
I never met more charming gen-
tlemen than those who dined us,
and was much surprised to find
that I was assigned to the second
place of honor, that is on President
Elliott's left (Gen. Wood being on his
right-) while our party includedly
several officers who ranked me- But
President Elliott said that my work enti-
tled me to the place of honor over
the others & he wanted me to know
how highly Boston appreciated my
work. I'll tell you more in my next
Dr Cabell has just ridden up in an
automobile & begged me to ride
with him & afterwards take supper
at the club - as he has something of
importance to talk over - says that
he will return for me in about
10 minutes - so I must cut my letter
I am so distressed about our fruit-trees.
Had I received your Wednesday's let
ters before I left, I would have
shipped you mosquito netting for
the younger trees- Did you try to
protect them with anything?- I hope
that you got something from Mr
Morrow's for that purpose- Do you
think that it's too late to do any
thing for them? If you think that
we can save any of them, when you
get this, telegraph me and I will
express a lot of mosquito netting
from Woodward & Lothrops-
Perhaps things are not so bad
as I fear- Please let me
know in your next- So glad
that you had a little rain-
Here comes Dr Cabell again
& I must stop- Love & kisses for
my precious babies- Keep Jacob
at work on the trees- Do pray put a
sheet around one or two-
